items.title: Six end of week links
items.summary:
Another week, more links. I‚Äôve split this up a bit and added a section of cool (open source) projects.

EVERY Gundam Timeline Explained - Tim Lyu breaks down every Gundam timeline and series in an incredible and obsessive fashion. I also watched his Evangelion breakdown too. youtube.com
Scams, Art Theft and NFTs - I like Brad Colbow‚Äôs thinking, from an artist‚Äôs perspective, around NFTs. youtube.com
Make Free Stuff - Max B√∂ck touches on one of my biggest concerns with Web3 in that it attempts ‚Äúto impose even more artificial locks and transactions on users, to extract even more money‚Äù, getting away from the Web‚Äôs anti-capitalist beginnings. mxb.dev

Omnichord - Jake Albaugh makes a free musical instrument using the Web Audio API. And it‚Äôs fun. Also, subdomains rule. omnichord.jake.fun
nuxt-cms-template - Alex Riviere and Andrew Walpole figured out how to integrate Netlify CMS‚Äôs block-based editor and preview feature with a Nuxt application. It may not sound like a big deal but getting a React app and a Nuxt app working together without creating a turducken is pretty intuitive. github.com
Accessible document workflow iwth Eleventy and Prince - Larry Hudson shows how to turn an Eleventy site into an accessible PDF using Prince. 11ty-prince-pdf-example.netlify.app

items.title: Before I go: When it comes to complaining about web browsers
items.summary:
I‚Äôm not planning on leaving the industry (yet), but before I go I‚Äôd like to offer up what I know when it comes to complaining about web browsers.
I have logged hundreds of hours complaining about browsers on Twitter, on podcasts, and on this blog. I have logged thousands more hours trying to keep up with browsers and I frequently interact with people who write specs and make browsers. I have not been 100% successful in my efforts to get a <rupert> element as my legacy but I have learned a lot about giving feedback to web browsers.
Browsers are really complex
Eric Meyer recently put it very well‚Ä¶

[W]eb browsers are actually 60fps+ rendering environments.  They‚Äôre First-Person Scrollers.

When you complain about browsers, the first thing you must know is: Browsers are big, complex pieces of software that must run very, very, very fast.
‚ÄúBrowsers should do _______‚Äù may sound like an easy feature, but have you considered that your idea might be a bad idea? Not just bad on paper, but bad on a bad for computers level. Browsers render the page at 60fps even while scrolling so your idea must work within a 4ms window‚Ä¶ along with the million other tasks the browser is trying to do during that same 4ms window.
To get your feature implemented you‚Äôll need either a giant pile of cash or the willing ear of someone who works on a browser. And then you‚Äôll need lots of consensus. Browsers are an exercise in consensus building; getting consensus for features inside your company, then shop it to web developers, then with other browsers, then you have to run the gauntlet through the official W3C working group tracks on the path to standardization. It‚Äôs consensus all the way down. Lots of input and lots of compromises along the way.
Let‚Äôs dig into some of the different ways we lay people can offer input and what I think works and doesn‚Äôt work based on past attempts.
Talking shit doesn‚Äôt work
Complaining on Twitter sure does feel good but it doesn‚Äôt do much other than burning bridges and burning through people‚Äôs patience. I guess you may also get hit with the mute button which is probably the opposite effect you were hoping for. Despite how good or valid your complaint is, combativeness results in immediate dismissal by your target audience‚Ä¶ not once, but for years. People hold grudges for a shockingly long time.
Jokes, snark, and sarcasm walk a thin line too. Exhibit A: I know some people at Google are a bit salty with me because I made a dumb joke on Twitter about <toast>, AMP, and Chrome seemingly over-exerting its dominant market share position in 2019. The irony here is I actually like the <std-element> pathway, but my commentary (punditry?) didn‚Äôt help as I joined the pile on, which was so bad that no one wants to ever try shipping native web components ever again.
Being toxic and abusive to the people that make browsers doesn‚Äôt add to the conversation. One possible goal it might achieve is amplifying feelings of burnout in the people you‚Äôre hoping will adopt your cause. We don‚Äôt need to be naive about business incentives (e.g. AMP, App Store revenue, developer mindshare landgrabs, etc) but we can dial back the heat a bit.
I recommend being specific about the features you need, curb the outrage.
Saying ‚Äúis the new IE‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work
To the previous point, lobbing general criticisms of monopolistic behaviors or constant out-of-datedness doesn‚Äôt help further the conversation. I agree that browsers probably need to go to court more for their behavior, but each browser company has its own historical baggage. Browser folk and fanboys will often deflect with whataboutism and invoke some kind of other finger pointing (Safari‚Äôs slow release cycle, Google‚Äôs data collection, Brave CEO‚Äôs support of California‚Äôs Prop 8 in 2007, Mozilla‚Äôs mass layoffs and dependency on Google Search money, Microsoft‚Äôs actual IE monopoly, etc). The criticism doesn‚Äôt land like it used to.
I‚Äôd recommend being specific about what features are missing and what is holding you back.
Yelling about privacy sort of works
Privacy is important and can raise security flags, but invoking privacy like a boogeyman doesn‚Äôt go far. Privacy is such a big topic, people (and corporations) often have different perspectives on what qualifies as a privacy invasion. Raise the flag, yes, it‚Äôs important to yell about what‚Äôs important but don‚Äôt let them run off and decide what ‚Äúprivacy‚Äù means.
It‚Äôs better to be specific about what privacy measures you are requesting.
And now for the best thing you could ever do‚Ä¶
Blogging your specific problems works
The best thing I‚Äôve ever done in my career is blog about my specific problems with browsers (or any software you‚Äôre passionate about). This goes for software beyond browsers too. I‚Äôve done this for IE, Safari, Edge, Firefox, Chrome, Windows 10, WSL and I‚Äôve seen first hand how a ‚Äúfriction log‚Äù can become a powerful tool in an organization.
Behind the scenes, your posts will get picked up by external-facing developer advocates and shared internally. A single blog post is worth 10,000 tweets. It‚Äôs valuable because it shows you thought through your problem and narrowed it down to a set of specific issues. All the more if it‚Äôs non-combative (see above). I‚Äôve seen this play out dozens of times.
A simplified example of a problem solved by Container Queries is a million times more helpful than an abusive ‚ÄúSupport Container Queries, ya fuckers‚Äù jab. A list of features causing expensive workarounds is great. If you‚Äôre blocked on a feature due to a lack of implementation‚Ä¶ blog it.
I‚Äôll even simplify this into to a user story for you:
When building [project]
I couldn't accomplish [task] 
Because [browser] 
Doesn't support [feature]

Add a bit more context or story there, edit out the drama, and I think you‚Äôve got a legitimate and useful criticism people can act on. You may even get on Hacker News (not that you‚Äôd want to do that). There may be times where you‚Äôll need to raise the social temperature on an issue, but you have to start here and outline the actual problems first.
Other activities that help
If intentionally collecting your thoughts and blogging sounds like too much, here‚Äôs some other entry points in providing feedback to browsers.

Responding to browser surveys helps - If you see someone from a browser ask for feedback, jump on it. These surveys turn into internal data that get put in powerpoint decks and shared around.
Starring issues helps - If a browser has an open bug tracker and you can star issues, do it. It sends a signal to engineers that this it‚Äôs an important request. No need to comment unless you have stack traces, a star is enough.
Saying ‚ÄúThank you‚Äù helps - You catch more flys with honey than you do with vinegar. If a browser or someone you know shipped a cool feature, say thank you. Give that person or team some recognition. Heck, they may even get promoted and have more internal leverage. Do that over and over and guess what, I bet if you have an actual complaint people will listen.
Making demos helps - Hear about a beta feature or an origin trial? Play with it! Find a way to crash the GPU? File a bug! Making demos in CodePens or some other sharable code format is probably the fastest way to become a person who gives feedback to browsers and they may even start reaching out to you for feedback first.

Wrapping up, there‚Äôs one more thing you can do‚Ä¶
Make other browsers better with this one weird trick
If you truly want other browsers to get better‚Ä¶ use other browsers! Money tends to follow eyeballs. Engineers get apportioned appropriately. And be sure to blog your troubles along the way.
Thus ends the imparting of what I know when it comes to complaining about web browsers.

Buckle up. This month turned out to be a big one. Writing it all out feels like an entire year went by, so I‚Äôll start with the bad that happened at the beginning of the month and move towards the good.
Got COVID
When I posted my Vibe Check ‚Ññ12 and End of 2021 posts, I noticed they were a bit emo as I felt ‚Äúexhausted‚Äù. Well, there was a reason for that: I had COVID. Those posts might need a giant asterisks applied to them. I still stand by that exhausted vibe because I was basically sick from December 17th to January 5th or so.
Thankfully ours was a ‚Äúmild‚Äù case and it did run thru the entire family. A lot of aches and sinus issues. We‚Äôre better now and resuming life. I‚Äôm like ~8% worried I have some mild form of Long COVID, but it‚Äôs allergy and mold season here in Austin so it‚Äôs hard to tell.
I don‚Äôt plan on getting COVID again, but if there‚Äôs a silver lining, it‚Äôs that at least the general fear of getting it has gone away. But that‚Äôs a me-centric perspective when 887,780+ people have passed away from this thing.
Rest in peace, Jackson
On January 4th a friend of our family unexpectedly passed away. Jackson taught me a lot over the years and had a helluva life story. During the civil war in his home country of Liberia, he and some other boys were taken out and left in the desert to die. He survived and came to the US as a young boy in a shipping container. He married (later divorced) and had four wonderful kids. Despite the challenges in his life, he always had an impossible sense of hope which could brighten your day.
Through Jackson I saw first hand how difficult the US immigration system is when a single stain on your record makes you a target for deportation. No pathways, delayed work permits, years of unemployment, immigration lawyers fees, health issues, doctors bills; I saw how unfair the system was to him and his family.
But he loved his kids. Every ounce of concern and every penny he made went to providing for his kids. His kids are nearly grown up now, the first is going off to college on scholarship, and I know they‚Äôre going to miss him but I know they know how much he loved them. It‚Äôs a sad situation to lose a dedicated parent in high school. If you can spare a prayer for Jackson‚Äôs kids and our neighbor Cleo (who was like a mother to Jackson), thank you.

2022: Be less disgusting - Whether it‚Äôs chewing with your mouth closed, not eating your boogers, or washing toothpaste down the sink instead of spitting it all over the bathroom counter‚Ä¶ plenty of chances to be less disgusting.

And for grown-ups, I got another one.

2022: Buy your happiness - It could be 2 years of the pandemic talking, or it could be because I kinda quit Twitter, but I have a hair-trigger on impulse purchases these days.

I hate how consumerist that is, but it‚Äôs a vibe so I‚Äôm keeping it. I hate how everything costs money but I‚Äôm embracing it right now instead of fighting it. Let me know if you have a good mantra for 2022!
Episode 500 of ShopTalk
I wrote about ShopTalk‚Äôs 500th episode so I won‚Äôt go in depth here, but that‚Äôs a lot of podcasting over the last ten years. I‚Äôve talked to lots of talented people through this podcast. 500 episodes is a pretty big career milestone and worth celebrating.
And celebrate I did! After the big recording I got myself a Grape Nerds Slush from Sonic. Special thanks to everyone who has helped make ShopTalk happen and thanks to everyone who has ever tuned in.

items.title: Five Hundred ShopTalks
items.summary:
Today Chris and I released the 500th episode of ShopTalk. That translates to 10 years of weekly episodes (taking off holiday breaks and that one time one of us had a kid). That‚Äôs a lot of showing up and doing the work. And when I say weekly, boy howdy, I mean weekly. Peeling back the curtain a bit, I think the most Chris and I have ever been ahead is two episodes. Every week at 11:00 AM Texas time Chris and I hop on a call, sometimes with some guests, sometimes without.
It‚Äôs interesting to have a first-hand chronicle to our industry‚Äôs ebbs and flows. When we started ShopTalk ‚Äúfront-end developer‚Äù wasn‚Äôt even a job title, WordPress was super cool, React didn‚Äôt exist, and people were starting to dip their toes into Sass. I switched operating systems and switched back. We delved into a handful of series that capture snapshots of the industry which I find offer up a neat vantage point of ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs happening now‚Äù from tons of different voices. I‚Äôm thankful to have had the opportunity to gain perspectives outside my own.
I‚Äôm lucky enough to have worked on some cool projects (I once made the Microsoft.com homepage in my spare bedroom), but ShopTalk stands out as a distinct career highlight due to its consistency over time. On a hard drive somewhere I have a graveyard of abandoned side projects, apps, podcasts, and games‚Ä¶ yet ShopTalk still stands. We log in every week and do it. Hopefully, getting a smidge better every time. Not all projects need to go 10+ years ‚Äî and that‚Äôs something I still need to learn, it‚Äôs okay for them to go away, they can and should change ‚Äî but it‚Äôs rewarding when you‚Äôre still having fun doing the thing you started doing so long ago. Fine wine, yadda yadda.
Lessons learned
The biggest lesson I‚Äôve learned about podcasting over the last 10 years: it‚Äôs all about consistency and quality. Releasing on a consistent day/week/etc (whatever that is for your show) and making sure the show you send to people‚Äôs earbuds and cars is a good quality audio file; that means good mic, good edit, decent music and audio cues.
For your podcast or (in more contemporary parlance) your livestream focus on finding one easy thing that can boost your quality. I‚Äôm a firm believer in the 80:20 rule, there‚Äôs often a trick you can do that makes your thing 80% better with 20% of the effort. Often that‚Äôs a microphone or learning proper mic technique. Figure it out for your situation, it‚Äôs worth it.
The other thing Chris and I talk about often is that whenever we‚Äôve needed to make a decision we‚Äôve always sided on making our lives easier and we have no regrets. This allows us to continue to enjoy the podcasting with less stress. For example, I use a USB mic with no audio interface, because easier. We don‚Äôt do high concept shows that often, because easier. We don‚Äôt typically have more than two guests, because easier. We pay an audio editor, because easier. ‚ÄúEasier‚Äù has been a good compass for us.
Looking forward
It‚Äôs tough to predict the future of ShopTalk, but it‚Äôs more of the same I think. We flamed out a bit on getting guests lined up during the pandemic but I think there‚Äôs energy to get back on track. We‚Äôve invested in our ‚Äústudio‚Äù a bit and are using Riverside.fm to make having guests and capturing quality audio even easier.
The biggest change going forward is that we‚Äôve branched out into video over on the CSS-Tricks YouTube channel. Be sure to smash that like button and subscribe. We‚Äôve made ~24 episodes since September which isn‚Äôt too shabby for a buncha dads.
The final thing is the ShopTalk D-D-D-Discord. We‚Äôve pivoted a smidge from being a broadcast-only podcast to being more of an active community. Lots of friendly folks in there now and because it‚Äôs a global chatroom so there‚Äôs messages and activity happening from when I wake up to when I go to bed. That‚Äôs exciting. There‚Äôs a lot more we could be doing (weekly hangouts or whatever) and hope to explore that more going forward.
And lastly,
Thanks to all the people we‚Äôve brought on board to help with the show. First was Aaron Dowd editing, then Chris Enns took over at the audio editor helm, the folks at BuySellAds helping sell ads, Tina Pham at Pham Transcription Services, Miranda Mulligan for helping us with the books, Chris Taylor for the theme songs, the D-D-D-Discord for inspiration, WordPress devs and plugin authors who have helped work on the site, and countless guests who have let us pick their brains over the years. Thanks to everyone who has helped out.
Thank you, dear listener, for downloading ShopTalk in your podcatcher of choice. It means a lot to me that you‚Äôd take the time to listen, even once. Thank you. Shopomaniacs 4 lyfe.
And finally, thanks to Chris Coyier, my partner in podcast crimes. It‚Äôs been a blast.
‚ÄúJust. Build. Websites.‚Äù

items.title: The Vacation
items.summary:
I situated myself in the premium white leather chair, lowered the rollercoaster-like safety harness over my torso, and carefully weighed options on the console in front of me.
> Evening . . . . . . . . 20/person
> Overnight . . . . . . . 100/person
> Weekend . . . . . . . . 250/person
> Week (BEST VALUE!)  . . 5000/family (Limit: 5)

I looked over my right shoulder to see my wife and kids‚Äô anxious faces gleaming back at me, ready with the nervous energy of a thousand suns to embark on our well-earned vacation. It‚Äôs been awhile. Some rough, lean years working like hell but through sacrifices and extreme budgeting we had finally saved up enough.
I hesitated to tap the screen. A nervous laugh. A moment of internal calculus. Maybe a handful of evenings would be enough. Would it have the same effect? A couple weekends would surely be enough to reset. More economical. And then we‚Äôd have a little left over, just in case.
I sensed my wife‚Äôs mind-reading. I sensed her fear I would succumb to my inner self-doubt. She has been working the hardest for this. Sacrificing to create these memories. I needed to shake those miser habits we‚Äôve formed out of years of austerity, what has become my identity.
‚ÄúOh, alright. Here we go,‚Äù I groaned and grimaced as I tapped the screen.
‚ÄúYou selected One Week‚Äù chimed the female voice of the console. Our chairs tilted slightly back, I felt the credits debit from my account, we were off. Finally.
The hiss of the pneumatic syringes, the sting on the spinal column, the cool and heavy breeze of the sedatives, the warm cocktail of endorphins and dopamine to stimulate our deepest dreams and desires, the chairs and harnesses catching our weight as we drifted away from consciousness. The lights in the room slowly dimmed. We would be back in a week.

items.title: The Hexagons and the Hexa-nots
items.summary:
It‚Äôs a secret to everyone! This post is for RSS subscribers only.
Read more about RSS Club.

Twitter released a feature that allows you to connect your crypto wallet to your Twitter account. Once you connect your wallet, you can set your profile picture to an NFT that you own.
I mean‚Ä¶ setting your profile picture (‚Äùpfp‚Äù) wasn‚Äôt a hard problem before. Right click > Save As, right? But this feature eliminates your phone‚Äôs camera roll as a middleman and instead inserts your wallet and the OpenSeas API as two third-party middlemen instead. If you‚Äôre wealthy enough to own enough NFTs that you have a hard time managing them all as profile pics, I suppose this is useful.
Ok. Whatever. Then Twitter‚Äôs implementation took it a step further and when you add your NFT as a pfp (which you could do before), it added a hexagonal clipping mask to NFT profile pictures. Users that have NFTs get a hexagon, users that don‚Äôt get regular old circles. That distinction, that ability to broadcast status, is now coded into the entire application.
It‚Äôs weird. NFT pfps already had a strong sense of in-group membership and status performance. You could already spot a crypto enthusiast by their gaudy, semi-generative, ape-themed or pixelated punk profile pic. Thousands of minted NFTs already had a consistent square format (for use as profile pictures) but Twitter added hexagons to the mix for‚Ä¶ pizazz? As a watermark to assert ownership?
The crypto community is not short on memes and social signifiers: apes, whales, pixel punks, diamond hands, to the moon, laser eyes, ‚Äúgm‚Äù, WAGMI, probably nothing, .eth usernames, and a slew of in-group words no one else uses like ‚Äúairdrop‚Äù, ‚Äúfiat‚Äù, ‚Äúpetrodollar‚Äù, etc. Plenty of indicators, why add another?
I shouldn‚Äôt get worked up about a shape, but what I specifically don‚Äôt like about the hexagons are that they create another form of ‚Äúotherism‚Äù; haves and have-nots. HODLers and NGMIs. Two camps. In-group and out-group. It‚Äôs creating division in a place where the world didn‚Äôt need any help creating division. The world doesn‚Äôt need more us versus them, yet we willingly apply feature glitter to increse the divide.
Somewhat apropos to this whole situation we‚Äôve found ourselves in, the hexagon is just a thin veneer of symbolism; a mask applied to the mundane giving it the appearance of something special. An illusion of value.
Transmitted via web2 for obvious reasons.

items.title: HTML is general, ARIA is specific
items.summary:
In Open UI there‚Äôs been some discussion about what default ARIA role the proposed <popupdialog> element should have, if any‚Ä¶
The proposed <popupdialog> element is a top-layer element that anchors to another element. Semantically, that‚Äôs a lot like a non-modal dialog, but people will probably use it incorrectly as a listbox, tooltip, combobox, etc. which are not a dialog and have their own more appropriate semantics. Should it be a dialog? Or should it be nothing like a <div> or a <span> but sits on the top layer of a website? Should we have other (similar) elements for those specific use cases? Is display: popup the best primitive here?
All good questions and I‚Äôm sure someone smarter than me will provide an answer.
What struck me about it all was how ARIA wants to be specific. It asks elements ‚ÄúWho are you deep down in your soul?‚Äù It‚Äôs a sentry at the gate, asking elements to identify themselves and if the element belongs to or fits within the known lexicon then there are well-defined interaction patterns that work with the Assistive Technology. It‚Äôs all useful and makes sense if you consider aural interfaces.
HTML, in my view, tends to be more general and permissive. A chill uncle. <div>? Sure, that can be a div. <article>? If you think that‚Äôs the article, great, let‚Äôs start there. <video>? Sure, send me some sources and I‚Äôll do my best otherwise I‚Äôll do nothing. Did you use a link for a <button> and a <button> for a link? Aww geeze, Rick. Wish you hadn‚Äôt done that. There‚Äôs right and wrong ways to do HTML, but there‚Äôs often more than one path to a solution. HTML provides a lot of building blocks, spicy divs and spicy spans, sometimes with built-in functionality and semantics, and other times the functionality it‚Äôs all bring-your-own.
There‚Äôs a tension there, but I think that‚Äôs what you get in a robust language designed to be liberal in what it accepts but conservative in what it does.

items.title: Sustaining Maintaining
items.summary:
You see it all the time; a repo with a thousand issues, a hundred open PRs, a thousand forks. v2.0 is on the way but there‚Äôs no clear roadmap or communication. Those of us who have worked on open source can spot it, burnout is afoot. The project got bigger than what the person or organization could realistically maintain. The maintainers are too busy or too burnt out to get the project back on track.
My open source burnout saga is pretty standard. My coworkers and I made a jQuery plugin that solved a hole in the web platform. It got pretty popular, and we made another one, and another one. Then the issues started pouring in; the surprise refactors, the undiscussed feature drops, the commit stat beefers, the good ideas I don‚Äôt have time for, the bad ideas I don‚Äôt know how to say ‚Äúno‚Äù to, and the endless ‚Äúthis doesn‚Äôt work and you‚Äôre a bad human‚Äù support requests.
The critical issue for me was that open source was counter-cyclical to my life. I‚Äôd open source in slow times, but couldn‚Äôt manage client work and open source work in busy times. Out of principle we don‚Äôt work on weekends at Paravel‚Ä¶ but people on GitHub sure do! Every Monday morning my inbox would be full of crushing guilt and neglected responsibility as issues piled up on my projects.
For every issue closed, three new issues showed up. I love open source, but it felt endless and unmanageable. As burnout encroached, I went into self-preservation mode. I did a bit here and there, but sought refuge for my mental health in video games and comic books instead of working nights and weekends. Years went by and having children deleted any concept of spare time.
It would be great if I had more time! But time requires money. Sentry and GitHub hosted a panel this week called ‚ÄúThe Future of Open Source: Is It Sustainable?‚Äù which was a candid discussion about funding. There‚Äôs different shapes funding can take, but most open source funding happens through either a dedicated employer, support contracts, a crowdfunding tip jar, or a foundation; the unifying factor seems to be maintainers get paid. Money helps make open source sustainable.
But financials are one part of the sustainable open source equation. There‚Äôs an emotional cost to having a publicly available project that hundreds or thousands of people and companies depend on as well. One of the best talks I‚Äôve heard on open source maintenance and one I reference often is Jacob Thornton‚Äôs 2012 dotJS talk ‚ÄúWhat Is Open Source & Why Do I Feel So Guilty?‚Äù

From the old Xerox PARC days to the open sourcing of Netscape in 1998 (which was the first use of the term ‚Äúopen source‚Äù) to the modern day npm install whatever-i-want; open source has come a long way. In ye olde times, we downloaded shareware from Sourceforge which was an effective way to install malware on your computer. GitHub‚Äôs launch in 2008 fundamentally changed how we build, share, and distribute software. It has even turned a proprietary titan like Microsoft into an open source advocate. The internet relies on people working for free.
Towards the end of the talk, Thornton gets to the heart of the issue:

With the acceleration of GitHub making everything more efficient, making everything easier and easier, the time to burnout is accelerating at a break neck pace.

‚ÄúBurnout‚Äù. There‚Äôs the word.
I sometimes wonder why a company like GitHub doesn‚Äôt offer educational, financial, or organizational support to maintainers. There‚Äôs plenty of write-ups on GitHub about how to start a new open source project, or how to add tooling, but almost no information or best practices on how to maintain a project over years. I think there‚Äôs a big education gap and opportunity here. GitHub has an obvious incentive to increase num_developers and num_repos,  but I think it‚Äôs worthwhile to ease the burden of existing developers and increase the quality and security of existing repos. Open source maintenance needs a manual.
If I were to spitball some chapter titles or sections for a manual, it‚Äôd look like this:

Differentiating between support requests and Issues
Issue management (issue templates, labels, sticky issues, closing strategies)
How to handle volume without losing your soul
Landing pull requests from strangers (security concerns, etc)
Setting up testing and continuous integration
How to get Sponsors
How and why to use Discussions
How and why to use Projects and Milestones
How to write good documentation
Setting boundaries and office hours
Effective and clear communication
Choosing an open source business model

Or what about offering in-person support? Developer Advocates could offer this list of services to project maintainers in exchange for livestream or video content. I‚Äôd love to see more content where existing projects get help on tooling or process instead of always starting from a blank repo. Call it ‚ÄúPimp My Repo‚Äù, get Xzibit to host, sell it to MTV. I‚Äôd watch it. I‚Äôd also watch interviews with successful maintainers to learn about their maintenance routines. It‚Äôd be beneficial to the open source community as a whole to replace the starving artist ‚Äîslash‚Äî burnt out maintainer trope with chilled out maintainers who have a good work/life balance.
I think there‚Äôs also a lot of opportunity for lessons in Open Source Citizenship education as well. Instead of endless ‚ÄúFuck you, fix my project‚Äù requests, there‚Äôs some hoops to jump through, some education, some reminder that there‚Äôs humans working for free on the other side of that comment box. CONTRIBUTING.md is a good step but contrast that with something like Discord‚Äôs welcome screen feature where you have to read and agree with a code of conduct before you can contribute. Anything to curb the entitlement and abuse is welcome. Onboarding people to the proper etiquette for filing a good bug report with proper repro steps or a reduced test case would go miles.
There‚Äôs also another idea out there: a ‚ÄúPay to Engage‚Äù model. You can read all the code, all the commits, all the issues, all the discussions, fork it, clone it, but if you want to engage and ask for help, you need to pay. Pay to Engage isn‚Äôt for every project and could hinder some projects, but it could unlock some sustainability.
These are ideas, I probably have a million more. And you probably have a million as well. I‚Äôd love to read your blog posts about it. If you maintain an open source project, what‚Äôs been successful for you on the marathon? What‚Äôs worked? What hasn‚Äôt? My weary soul wants to know.

items.title: Status Performance Analysis in Team Fortress 2
items.summary:
In 2013 Chong-U Lim wrote a research paper for MIT wordily titled Modeling Player Performance in Avatar Customization Using Social Network Data: A Case Study Using Virtual Items in Team Fortress 2. It‚Äôs all about the correlation between in-game loot ‚Äîdigital items people win or buy on the Steam marketplace‚Äî and player‚Äôs social status in an online competitive game called Team Fortress 2. What a phenomenal research topic! It‚Äôs a dense paper, so thankfully Tommy Thompson at the AI & Games YouTube channel breaks it down.
One interesting piece was how the study talks about players creating a ‚Äúphantasmal identity‚Äù ‚Äîa projection of real-world human ideas onto a digital avatar‚Äî and how the player‚Äôs identity is often projected in a ‚Äúridiculous and exaggerated fashion‚Äù. A machine learning model was able to classify and predict (with ~60% accuracy) a player‚Äôs social status (social interactions) based on their status performance (value of in-game hats). I think about this often, because it‚Äôs a fascinating look at the relationship between digital cosmetics (hats, skins, avatars, sprays) and social status broadcasting. Louis Vuitton, but Loot Boxes.
Anyways‚Ä¶ NFTs

items.summary:
It‚Äôs a secret to everyone! This post is for RSS subscribers only.
Read more about RSS Club.

Twitter has been fever-pitched about Web3, blockchain, and NFTs. It‚Äôs made it an unenjoyable place for me as more and more people I follow chase the money over to Web3. Everything is getting an NFT feature: Twitter, Discord, Reddit, Disney+, Star Trek; it‚Äôs exhausting.
I spent a lot of time and emotional well-being last month thinking (aka ‚Äúdoing my own research‚Äù) about Web3 and NFTs. I‚Äôm not morally opposed to ledger-like problems that blockchain can solve and DAOs even sound great; but the surface area for criminal activity, unregulated markets, no consumer protection, fake scarcity to drive up values, low-quality art being cheaply made selling at inflated values, thousands of 500 watt GPUs glowing in a basement in Iowa destroying the environment for a profile picture‚Ä¶ Ugh.
NFTs are sucking the air out of everything‚Ä¶ both literally and figuratively.
Two weeks ago I uninstalled Twitter from my devices. Waking up in the morning I‚Äôm no longer greeted with a million angry voices. No faux conservative outrage, no reactive liberal outrage. It can all be undone in an instant, but right now I‚Äôm unplugged from the infernal machine and it feels unsettingly quiet.

items.title: Gaming improved my EQ
items.summary:
Gamers aren‚Äôt known for being the most intelligent people around‚Ä¶
Oh no Tim... üåé@timthetatman pic.twitter.com/njLv2c59Jy‚Äî Wipz (@Wipz) July 29, 2020 
While IQ may be at an all time low, I think there‚Äôs actually a wealth of emotional intelligence (EQ) within competitive gaming. It‚Äôs un-gamer to even talk about this, but there‚Äôs some words in the gaming vernacular that give language to some complex emotions:

nerf - a stat decrease, something that was good is now worse due to an externality
buff - a stat increase, something that was bad is now better due to an externality
salty - ambient negativity, usually apparent in language and outbursts.
toxic - active negativity to the extent that words or behaviors effect the well-being of the game/group.
tilted - angered to a point where it‚Äôs negatively effecting your personal performance.
meta - what‚Äôs popular, typically a character or weapon that is has a high pick rate and/or offers some competitive advantage.
meta shift - when the existing meta changes due to nerfs, buffs, or newly discovered techniques.
mental - your state of mind, mental game, e.g. ‚Äúprotect your mental‚Äù.
chalked - dead, done for, broken, not worth pursuing.
blender - a series of repeating failures, e.g. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in a blender‚Äù
game sense - your understanding of the map or environment, positioning, enemy assessment, and win conditions
psychic damage - long lasting damage effects that last multiple rounds (this one is from D&D)

Through gaming, I‚Äôm attuned to what it feels like to be tilted. I‚Äôm know when upset ‚Äî a hijacking of my amygdala ‚Äî and I know that makes me play bad and then I‚Äôm more upset and I play worse‚Ä¶ a classic negative feedback loop. Squadmates can sense this in each other too and can try to help each other reset (or call each other out), but sometimes turning off the computer is the best course of action.
Taking that into my daily life, knowing when I‚Äôm tilted ‚Äîwhether it be by some meeting, a global pandemic, or a child whittling on your last nerve‚Äî I know that feeling. Because of gaming, I know when I need to reset, I know how to reset (read, sleep), and I find myself having an easier time stepping back. I know when I have an unnecessary, salty, bitchy attitude about some predicament. I can almost taste it. Acknowledging when I‚Äôm in a blender helps let the psychic damage roll over me, like diving under a crashing wave. Get through it, it‚Äôll turn around.
The concept of meta shifts is interesting too. When a meta shifts in a video game it can be  frustrating that your old tricks and characters don‚Äôt work anymore. It‚Äôs feels like you lost all game sense and your controller no longer works. Extrapolating that to meta shifts in technology has given verbiage to something I felt in my work life but couldn‚Äôt articulate. That feeling when the tools I use and the technology I‚Äôve invested in are no longer cool any more, or even talked down upon. When the meta shifts on you, you feel irreparably behind the curve and you‚Äôre crushed with the feeling you need to re-learn everything to level up your skills on the new meta. It‚Äôs exhausting, leads to burnout, and you want to uninstall yourself from tech; but I think there‚Äôs power in understanding you‚Äôre in a meta shift.
Cooperative games (video, tabletop, etc) also give you an understanding that each person in an organization has a role to play. A lot of games you select a character class and you learn that how you measure performance looks different. A DPS (damage per second) player should deal damage, a tank player should take damage, and a support player should remove damage. There‚Äôs not one uniform metric for success, if you measure solely on damage dealt that skews the reality of how success happens.
Bringing this full circle, even your worst performing player ‚Äî who it would be easy to throw under the bus ‚Äî might be adding immeasurable value‚Ä¶
A message to the worst one on the team... pic.twitter.com/pJIuaTE5Mc‚Äî timthetatmanüëë (@timthetatman) January 13, 2021 
Adding value as ‚Äúthe anchor‚Äù. That‚Äôs some EQ for ya.

items.summary:
Frustrated by the emotional weight of hundreds of thoughts lingering in my blogging kanban, I chucked a good bit of time into a week of high-powered blogging and achieved great results. Garnered eight blog posts this month and a one week streak. One of the best months of blogging I‚Äôve had in a good while.
I needed to flush ideas out so that I could start to focus on other more interesting ideas. With those out of the way, I can make room for other thoughts or what I secretly want to do: write shitty science fiction. Between blog posts, YouTubes, and podcasts; this month it felt like the Dave Rupert Content Engine‚Ñ¢ was working.
I hoped to post a bit more in Blogtober, but my family‚Äôs plans changed a bit as my wife‚Äôs grandmother passed away. What balance I was thriving on was shaken up by a death in the family. I still have half-a-dozen posts on deck, so I‚Äôm optimistic momentum can continue into November as I purge ideas out of the queue.
Goodbye Grandma Jeanne
My wife‚Äôs grandma Jeanne was a wonderful woman who lived in-and-around Bakersfield, California her whole life. She had a full 89 years of life and after a rough summer of mystery health problems this summer culminating in a stroke and a case of pneumonia, she moved on from this world. She will be deeply missed.
She was a sharp and clever woman; a loving wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother, and friend. Dedicated to her church and would never miss a chance to let you know she‚Äôs praying for you. She leaves behind her a great legacy and some lucky ones have inherited her singing voice.
I never knew my great grandparents, so I think it‚Äôs special that my kids will at least have some memory of Great Grandma Jeanne. It‚Äôs a good thing when families can span generations and dinners with ‚Äúcousins‚Äù occupy a whole wing of a restaurant.
The case of the ill-fitting jacket
While trying on jackets for the funeral, I found an almost perfect jacket at J. Crew. Disappointment set in as it felt the smallest bit short when I tried it on. The dressing room associate pointed out the jacket was actually normal but because my distended belly was so fat, the jacket was pulling up. He might have said it nicer, but not much nicer.
That‚Ä¶ uh‚Ä¶ wasn‚Äôt a great feeling. But I did learn that in a 2020s world where everything is slim fits, I‚Äôm a 1990s-sized regular. Only husky 90s kids get this.
Thus‚Ä¶ I guess November is Health Month. I‚Äôm already taking steps but the bulk of my issues come down to prioritizing myself. Will need to focus on that, but it‚Äôs hard with wife and kids and whatnot. If you‚Äôre good at prioritizing yourself ‚Äî awesome ‚Äî I literally don‚Äôt want to hear a fucking word from you. If you‚Äôre bad at it, oh nice, me too, I‚Äôd love to commiserate.
Autumnal Camping

My kids hold beef. And they hold it forever. If one kid in the neighborhood did something they‚Äôll talk about it every other day like it happened yesterday. The friend‚Äôs neighbor who is slightly younger but was annoying once? Annoying forever! Even if you‚Äôve played with him since! That new friend who said she saw a dinosaur in her backyard? A liar.         <title>Before I go: When it comes to complaining about web browsers</title>
        <description><p>I‚Äôm not planning on leaving the industry (yet), but before I go I‚Äôd like to offer up what I know when it comes to complaining about web browsers.</p>
<p>I have logged hundreds of hours complaining about browsers on Twitter, on podcasts, and on this blog. I have logged thousands more hours trying to keep up with browsers and I frequently interact with people who write specs and make browsers. I have not been 100% successful in my efforts to get a <code>&lt;rupert&gt;</code> element as my legacy but I have learned a lot about giving feedback to web browsers.</p>
<h2>Browsers are really complex</h2>
<p><a href="https://twitter.com/meyerweb/status/1490174570413838339?s=20&amp;t=yk9oY0QapQ39L4wTS_WoWA">Eric Meyer recently put it very well</a>‚Ä¶</p>
<blockquote>
<p>[W]eb browsers are actually 60fps+ rendering environments.  They‚Äôre First-Person Scrollers.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>When you complain about browsers, the first thing you must know is: Browsers are big, complex pieces of software that must run very, very, very fast.</p>
<p>‚ÄúBrowsers should do _______‚Äù may sound like an easy feature, but have you considered that your idea might be a <em>bad idea</em>? Not just <em>bad on paper</em>, but bad on a <em>bad for computers</em> level. Browsers render the page at 60fps even while scrolling so your idea must work within a 4ms window‚Ä¶ along with the million other tasks the browser is trying to do during that same 4ms window.</p>
<p>To get your feature implemented you‚Äôll need either a giant pile of cash or the willing ear of someone who works on a browser. And then you‚Äôll need lots of consensus. Browsers are an exercise in consensus building; getting consensus for features inside your company, then shop it to web developers, then with other browsers, then you have to run the gauntlet through the official W3C working group tracks on the path to standardization. It‚Äôs consensus all the way down. Lots of input and lots of compromises along the way.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs dig into some of the different ways we lay people can offer input and what I think works and doesn‚Äôt work based on past attempts.</p>
<h2>Talking shit doesn‚Äôt work</h2>
<p>Complaining on Twitter sure does feel good but it doesn‚Äôt do much other than burning bridges and burning through people‚Äôs patience. I guess you may also get hit with the mute button which is probably the opposite effect you were hoping for. Despite how good or valid your complaint is, combativeness results in immediate dismissal by your target audience‚Ä¶ not once, but for years. People hold grudges for a shockingly long time.</p>
<p>Jokes, snark, and sarcasm walk a thin line too. Exhibit A: I know some people at Google are a bit salty with me because <a href="https://twitter.com/davatron5000/status/1139151671672676353">I made a dumb joke on Twitter</a> about <code>&lt;toast&gt;</code>, AMP, and Chrome seemingly over-exerting its dominant market share position in 2019. The irony here is I actually like the <code>&lt;std-element&gt;</code> pathway, but my commentary (punditry?) didn‚Äôt help as I joined the pile on, which was so bad that no one wants to ever try shipping native web components ever again.</p>
<p>Being toxic and abusive to the people that make browsers doesn‚Äôt add to the conversation. One possible goal it might achieve is amplifying feelings of burnout in the people you‚Äôre hoping will adopt your cause. We don‚Äôt need to be naive about business incentives (e.g. AMP, App Store revenue, developer mindshare landgrabs, etc) but we can dial back the heat a bit.</p>
<p>I recommend being specific about the features you need, curb the outrage.</p>
<h2>Saying ‚Äúis the new IE‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work</h2>
<p>To the previous point, lobbing general criticisms of monopolistic behaviors or constant out-of-datedness doesn‚Äôt help further the conversation. I agree that browsers probably need to go to court more for their behavior, but each browser company has its own historical baggage. Browser folk and fanboys will often deflect with <em>whataboutism</em> and invoke some kind of other finger pointing (Safari‚Äôs slow release cycle, Google‚Äôs data collection, Brave CEO‚Äôs support of California‚Äôs Prop 8 in 2007, Mozilla‚Äôs mass layoffs and dependency on Google Search money, Microsoft‚Äôs actual IE monopoly, etc). The criticism doesn‚Äôt land like it used to.</p>
<p>I‚Äôd recommend being specific about what features are missing and what is holding you back.</p>
<h2>Yelling about privacy sort of works</h2>
<p>Privacy is important and can raise security flags, but invoking privacy like a boogeyman doesn‚Äôt go far. Privacy is such a big topic, people (and corporations) often have different perspectives on what qualifies as a privacy invasion. Raise the flag, yes, it‚Äôs important to yell about what‚Äôs important but don‚Äôt let them run off and decide what ‚Äúprivacy‚Äù means.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs better to be specific about what privacy measures you are requesting.</p>
<p>And now for the best thing you could ever do‚Ä¶</p>
<h2>Blogging your specific problems works</h2>
<p>The best thing I‚Äôve ever done in my career is blog about my specific problems with browsers (or any software you‚Äôre passionate about). This goes for software beyond browsers too. I‚Äôve done this for IE, Safari, Edge, Firefox, Chrome, Windows 10, WSL and I‚Äôve seen first hand how a ‚Äúfriction log‚Äù can become a powerful tool in an organization.</p>
<p>Behind the scenes, your posts will get picked up by external-facing developer advocates and shared internally. A single blog post is worth 10,000 tweets. It‚Äôs valuable because it shows you thought through your problem and narrowed it down to a set of specific issues. All the more if it‚Äôs non-combative (see above). I‚Äôve seen this play out dozens of times.</p>
<p>A simplified example of a problem solved by Container Queries is a million times more helpful than an abusive ‚ÄúSupport Container Queries, ya fuckers‚Äù jab. A list of features causing expensive workarounds is great. If you‚Äôre blocked on a feature due to a lack of implementation‚Ä¶ blog it.</p>
<p>I‚Äôll even simplify this into to a user story for you:</p>
<pre><code class="language-markdown">When building [project]
I couldn't accomplish [task] 
Because [browser] 
Doesn't support [feature]
</code></pre>
<p>Add a bit more context or story there, edit out the drama, and I think you‚Äôve got a legitimate and useful criticism people can act on. You may even get on Hacker News (not that you‚Äôd want to do that). There may be times where you‚Äôll need to raise the social temperature on an issue, but you have to start here and outline the actual problems first.</p>
<h2>Other activities that help</h2>
<p>If intentionally collecting your thoughts and blogging sounds like too much, here‚Äôs some other entry points in providing feedback to browsers.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Responding to browser surveys helps</strong> - If you see someone from a browser ask for feedback, jump on it. These surveys turn into internal data that get put in powerpoint decks and shared around.</li>
<li><strong>Starring issues helps</strong> - If a browser has an open bug tracker and you can star issues, do it. It sends a signal to engineers that this it‚Äôs an important request. No need to comment unless you have stack traces, a star is enough.</li>
<li><strong>Saying ‚ÄúThank you‚Äù helps</strong> - You catch more flys with honey than you do with vinegar. If a browser or someone you know shipped a cool feature, say thank you. Give that person or team some recognition. Heck, they may even get promoted and have more internal leverage. Do that over and over and guess what, I bet if you have an actual complaint people will listen.</li>
<li><strong>Making demos helps</strong> - Hear about a beta feature or an origin trial? Play with it! Find a way to crash the GPU? File a bug! Making demos in CodePens or some other sharable code format is probably the fastest way to become a person who gives feedback to browsers and they may even start reaching out to you for feedback first.</li>
</ul>
<p>Wrapping up, there‚Äôs one more thing you can do‚Ä¶</p>
<h2>Make other browsers better with this one weird trick</h2>
<p>If you truly want other browsers to get better‚Ä¶ <strong>use other browsers</strong>! Money tends to follow eyeballs. Engineers get apportioned appropriately. And be sure to blog your troubles along the way.</p>
<p>Thus ends the imparting of what I know when it comes to complaining about web browsers.</p>
</description>

        <title>Vibe Check ‚Ññ13</title>
        <description><p>Buckle up. This month turned out to be a big one. Writing it all out feels like an entire year went by, so I‚Äôll start with the bad that happened at the beginning of the month and move towards the good.</p>
<h2>Got COVID</h2>
<p>When I posted my <a href="https://daverupert.com/2021/12/vibe-check-12/">Vibe Check ‚Ññ12</a> and <a href="https://daverupert.com/2021/12/twenty-twentyone/">End of 2021</a> posts, I noticed they were a bit emo as I felt ‚Äúexhausted‚Äù. Well, there was a reason for that: I had COVID. Those posts might need a giant asterisks applied to them. I still stand by that exhausted vibe because I was basically sick from December 17th to January 5th or so.</p>
<p>Thankfully ours was a ‚Äúmild‚Äù case and it did run thru the entire family. A lot of aches and sinus issues. We‚Äôre better now and resuming life. I‚Äôm like ~8% worried I have some mild form of Long COVID, but it‚Äôs allergy and mold season here in Austin so it‚Äôs hard to tell.</p>
<p>I don‚Äôt plan on getting COVID again, but if there‚Äôs a silver lining, it‚Äôs that at least the general fear of getting it has gone away. But that‚Äôs a me-centric perspective when 887,780+ people have passed away from this thing.</p>
<h2>Rest in peace, Jackson</h2>
<p>On January 4th a friend of our family unexpectedly passed away. Jackson taught me a lot over the years and had a helluva life story. During the civil war in his home country of Liberia, he and some other boys were taken out and left in the desert to die. He survived and came to the US as a young boy in a shipping container. He married (later divorced) and had four wonderful kids. Despite the challenges in his life, he always had an impossible sense of hope which could brighten your day.</p>
<p>Through Jackson I saw first hand how difficult the US immigration system is when a single stain on your record makes you a target for deportation. No pathways, delayed work permits, years of unemployment, immigration lawyers fees, health issues, doctors bills; I saw how unfair the system was to him and his family.</p>
<p>But he loved his kids. Every ounce of concern and every penny he made went to providing for his kids. His kids are nearly grown up now, the first is going off to college on scholarship, and I know they‚Äôre going to miss him but I know they know how much he loved them. It‚Äôs a sad situation to lose a dedicated parent in high school. If you can spare a prayer for Jackson‚Äôs kids and our neighbor Cleo (who was like a mother to Jackson), thank you.</p>
<h2>2022 Mantras</h2>
<p>It‚Äôs been a rough start to the year for sure, but we‚Äôre getting through it. I find it‚Äôs good to have some operating principles for the year, so I‚Äôve been workshopping some mantras with the kids. ‚Äú2020: Learn to take a picture‚Äù didn‚Äôt pan out but I think we got some good ones this year.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>2022: Do stuff you can do (without a parent)</strong> - I love my kids but they need to learn how to get their own glass of water at this point.</li>
<li><strong>2022: Be less disgusting</strong> - Whether it‚Äôs chewing with your mouth closed, not eating your boogers, or washing toothpaste down the sink instead of spitting it all over the bathroom counter‚Ä¶ plenty of chances to be less disgusting.</li>
</ul>
<p>And for grown-ups, I got another one.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>2022: Buy your happiness</strong> - It could be 2 years of the pandemic talking, or it could be because I kinda quit Twitter, but I have a hair-trigger on impulse purchases these days.</li>
</ul>
<p>I hate how <a href="https://daverupert.com/2019/06/the-three-evils-of-society/">consumerist</a> that is, but it‚Äôs a vibe so I‚Äôm keeping it. I hate how everything costs money but I‚Äôm embracing it right now instead of fighting it. Let me know if you have a good mantra for 2022!</p>
<h2>Episode 500 of ShopTalk</h2>
<p><a href="https://daverupert.com/2022/01/five-hundred-shoptalks/">I wrote about ShopTalk‚Äôs 500th episode</a> so I won‚Äôt go in depth here, but that‚Äôs a lot of podcasting over the last ten years. I‚Äôve talked to lots of talented people through this podcast. 500 episodes is a pretty big career milestone and worth celebrating.</p>
<p>And celebrate I did! After the big recording I got myself a Grape Nerds Slush from Sonic. Special thanks to everyone who has helped make ShopTalk happen and thanks to everyone who has ever tuned in.</p>
<h2>I built my first Gunpla</h2>
<p><img src="/images/posts/2022/gunpla.jpg" alt="A small plastic model Gundam robot" /></p>
<p>On a whim (remember: buy your happiness) I bought my first entry-grade Gunpla. ‚ÄúGunpla‚Äù („Ç¨„É≥„Éó„É©) is a shortened form of the phrase ‚ÄúGundam Plastic Model‚Äù in Japanese. It‚Äôs a hobby where you build little anime robots out of pre-colored, press-fit plastic parts. Building a Gunpla model produces an incredibly good, ASMR-like sensation. Way better than western models where you need to prime, paint, and painstakingly glue everything together. Gunpla is more like LEGO where you zen-fully cut out pieces, snap them together, and end up with a fully articulated robot.</p>
<p>Making my first Gunpla spawned a micro-obsession of learning all about Gunpla; the different grades, the different eras, the different manufacturers, panel lining, fine tip versus pour fill markers, and so on. I‚Äôve learned a lot of useless facts. But it‚Äôs also spawned a desire to do more handicrafts.</p>
<p>I have <a href="https://kbdfans.com/products/ic-kbdfans-mountain-ergo-keyboard-kit?variant=39809723039883">a new ergonomic keyboard</a> to build, a book of <a href="https://amzn.to/3s4c1Yi">Frank Lloyd Wright <em>kirigami</em> papercraft models</a>, and of course more Gunpla. I think this new hobby is directly related to logging out of Twitter this month, so I‚Äôm going to ride this vibe out and be a bit more analog in my after hours.</p>
<h2>Another big refactor on Luro</h2>
<p>One of the biggest months ever behind the scenes on <a href="https://luroapp.com/">Luro</a>. We refactored a bunch of code to make the spinning up installations for new customers a lot easier. This involved removing a MongoDB server and folding our serverless API, node server API, and Nuxt app into a single monolithic Node app. While a ‚Äúmonolith‚Äù sounds like a step backwards from a <em>tech de jour</em> it has radically simplified the number of moving parts from 6‚Üí3 and better fits our customer goals well.</p>
<p><strong>tl;dr</strong>‚Äî We‚Äôre in a much better ‚Äúit just works‚Äù state with <a href="http://boringtechnology.club/">boring technology</a>, it‚Äôs a lot easier to run all the parts locally and it‚Äôs a lot easier to deploy and a lot easier to get to customers. Exciting days ahead.</p>

      <item>
        <title>Five Hundred ShopTalks</title>
        <description><p>Today <a href="https://chriscoyier.net/">Chris</a> and I released the <a href="https://shoptalkshow.com/500/">500th episode of ShopTalk</a>. That translates to 10 years of weekly episodes (taking off holiday breaks and that one time one of us had a kid). That‚Äôs a lot of showing up and doing the work. And when I say weekly, boy howdy, I mean weekly. Peeling back the curtain a bit, I think the most Chris and I have ever been ahead is two episodes. Every week at 11:00 AM Texas time Chris and I hop on a call, sometimes with some guests, sometimes without.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs interesting to have a first-hand chronicle to our industry‚Äôs ebbs and flows. When we started ShopTalk ‚Äúfront-end developer‚Äù wasn‚Äôt even a job title, WordPress was super cool, React didn‚Äôt exist, and people were starting to dip their toes into Sass. <a href="https://shoptalkshow.com/186-dave-goes-windows/">I switched operating systems</a> and <a href="https://shoptalkshow.com/443/">switched back</a>. We delved into a handful of <a href="https://shoptalkshow.com/series/">series that capture snapshots of the industry</a> which I find offer up a neat vantage point of ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs happening now‚Äù from tons of different voices. I‚Äôm thankful to have had the opportunity to gain perspectives outside my own.</p>
<p>I‚Äôm lucky enough to have worked on some cool projects (I once made the <a href="http://Microsoft.com">Microsoft.com</a> homepage in my spare bedroom), but ShopTalk stands out as a distinct career highlight due to its consistency over time. On a hard drive somewhere I have a graveyard of abandoned side projects, apps, podcasts, and games‚Ä¶ yet ShopTalk still stands. We log in every week and do it. Hopefully, getting a smidge better every time. Not all projects need to go 10+ years ‚Äî and that‚Äôs something I still need to learn, it‚Äôs okay for them to go away, they can and should change ‚Äî but it‚Äôs rewarding when you‚Äôre still having fun doing the thing you started doing so long ago. Fine wine, yadda yadda.</p>
<h2>Lessons learned</h2>
<p>The biggest lesson I‚Äôve learned about podcasting over the last 10 years: it‚Äôs all about <strong>consistency</strong> and <strong>quality</strong>. Releasing on a consistent day/week/etc (whatever that is for your show) and making sure the show you send to people‚Äôs earbuds and cars is a good quality audio file; that means good mic, good edit, decent music and audio cues.</p>
<p>For your podcast or (in more contemporary parlance) your livestream focus on finding one easy thing that can boost your quality. I‚Äôm a firm believer in the 80:20 rule, there‚Äôs often a trick you can do that makes your thing 80% better with 20% of the effort. Often that‚Äôs a microphone or learning proper mic technique. Figure it out for your situation, it‚Äôs worth it.</p>
<p>The other thing Chris and I talk about often is that whenever we‚Äôve needed to make a decision we‚Äôve always sided on making our lives easier and we have no regrets. This allows us to continue to enjoy the podcasting with less stress. For example, I use a USB mic with no audio interface, because easier. We don‚Äôt do high concept shows that often, because easier. We don‚Äôt typically have more than two guests, because easier. We pay an audio editor, because easier. ‚ÄúEasier‚Äù has been a good compass for us.</p>
<h2>Looking forward</h2>
<p>It‚Äôs tough to predict the future of ShopTalk, but it‚Äôs more of the same I think. We flamed out a bit on getting guests lined up during the pandemic but I think there‚Äôs energy to get back on track. We‚Äôve invested in our ‚Äústudio‚Äù a bit and are using <a href="http://Riverside.fm">Riverside.fm</a> to make having guests and capturing quality audio even easier.</p>
<p>The biggest change going forward is that <a href="https://shoptalkshow.com/video/">we‚Äôve branched out into video</a> over on the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/realcsstricks">CSS-Tricks YouTube channel</a>. Be sure to smash that like button and subscribe. We‚Äôve made ~24 episodes since September which isn‚Äôt too shabby for a buncha dads.</p>
<p>The final thing is the ShopTalk D-D-D-Discord. We‚Äôve pivoted a smidge from being a broadcast-only podcast to being more of an active community. Lots of friendly folks in there now and because it‚Äôs a global chatroom so there‚Äôs messages and activity happening from when I wake up to when I go to bed. That‚Äôs exciting. There‚Äôs a lot more we could be doing (weekly hangouts or whatever) and hope to explore that more going forward.</p>
<h2>And lastly,</h2>
<p>Thanks to all the people we‚Äôve brought on board to help with the show. First was <a href="https://www.aarondowd.com/">Aaron Dowd</a> editing, then <a href="https://www.lemonproductions.ca/">Chris Enns</a> took over at the audio editor helm, the folks at BuySellAds helping sell ads, Tina Pham at <a href="https://phamtranscriptionservices.com/">Pham Transcription Services</a>, Miranda Mulligan for helping us with the books, <a href="https://www.stillbreathing.co.uk/">Chris Taylor</a> for the theme songs, <a href="https://www.patreon.com/shoptalkshow">the D-D-D-Discord</a> for inspiration, WordPress devs and plugin authors who have helped work on the site, and countless guests who have let us pick their brains over the years. Thanks to everyone who has helped out.</p>
<p>Thank you, dear listener, for downloading ShopTalk in your podcatcher of choice. It means a lot to me that you‚Äôd take the time to listen, even once. Thank you. Shopomaniacs 4 lyfe.</p>
<p>And finally, thanks to Chris Coyier, my partner in podcast crimes. It‚Äôs been a blast.</p>
<p>‚ÄúJust. Build. Websites.‚Äù</p>
</description>

        <title>The Vacation</title>
        <description><p>I situated myself in the premium white leather chair, lowered the rollercoaster-like safety harness over my torso, and carefully weighed options on the console in front of me.</p>
<pre><code class="language-bash">&gt; Evening . . . . . . . . 20/person
&gt; Overnight . . . . . . . 100/person
&gt; Weekend . . . . . . . . 250/person
&gt; Week (BEST VALUE!)  . . 5000/family (Limit: 5)
</code></pre>
<p>I looked over my right shoulder to see my wife and kids‚Äô anxious faces gleaming back at me, ready with the nervous energy of a thousand suns to embark on our well-earned vacation. It‚Äôs been awhile. Some rough, lean years working like hell but through sacrifices and extreme budgeting we had finally saved up enough.</p>
<p>I hesitated to tap the screen. A nervous laugh. A moment of internal calculus. Maybe a handful of evenings would be enough. Would it have the same effect? A couple weekends would surely be enough to reset. More economical. And then we‚Äôd have a little left over, just in case.</p>
<p>I sensed my wife‚Äôs mind-reading. I sensed her fear I would succumb to my inner self-doubt. She has been working the hardest for this. Sacrificing to create these memories. I needed to shake those miser habits we‚Äôve formed out of years of austerity, what has become my identity.</p>
<p>‚ÄúOh, alright. Here we go,‚Äù I groaned and grimaced as I tapped the screen.</p>
<p>‚ÄúYou selected <code>One Week</code>‚Äù chimed the female voice of the console. Our chairs tilted slightly back, I felt the credits debit from my account, we were off. Finally.</p>
<p>The hiss of the pneumatic syringes, the sting on the spinal column, the cool and heavy breeze of the sedatives, the warm cocktail of endorphins and dopamine to stimulate our deepest dreams and desires, the chairs and harnesses catching our weight as we drifted away from consciousness. The lights in the room slowly dimmed. We would be back in a week.</p>
</description>

        <title>The Hexagons and the Hexa-nots</title>
        <description><p><tt>It‚Äôs a secret to everyone! This post is for RSS subscribers only.
<a href="https://daverupert.com/rss-club/">Read more about RSS Club</a>.
</tt></p>
<p>Twitter released a feature that allows you to connect your crypto wallet to your Twitter account. Once you connect your wallet, you can set your profile picture to an NFT that you own.</p>
<p>I mean‚Ä¶ setting your profile picture (‚Äùpfp‚Äù) wasn‚Äôt a hard problem before. Right click &gt; Save As, right? But this feature eliminates your phone‚Äôs camera roll as a middleman and instead inserts your wallet and the OpenSeas API as two third-party middlemen instead. If you‚Äôre wealthy enough to own enough NFTs that you have a hard time managing them all as profile pics, I suppose this is useful.</p>
<p>Ok. Whatever. Then Twitter‚Äôs implementation took it a step further and when you add your NFT as a pfp (which you could do before), it added a hexagonal clipping mask to NFT profile pictures. Users that have NFTs get a hexagon, users that don‚Äôt get regular old circles. That distinction, that ability to broadcast status, is now coded into the entire application.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs weird. NFT pfps already had a strong sense of in-group membership and <a href="https://daverupert.com/2021/11/tf2-hats/">status performance</a>. You could already spot a crypto enthusiast by their gaudy, semi-generative, ape-themed or pixelated punk profile pic. Thousands of minted NFTs already had a consistent square format (for use as profile pictures) but Twitter added hexagons to the mix for‚Ä¶ pizazz? As a watermark to assert ownership?</p>
<p>The crypto community is not short on memes and social signifiers: apes, whales, pixel punks, diamond hands, to the moon, laser eyes, ‚Äúgm‚Äù, WAGMI, probably nothing, <code>.eth</code> usernames, and a slew of in-group words no one else uses like ‚Äúairdrop‚Äù, ‚Äúfiat‚Äù, ‚Äúpetrodollar‚Äù, etc. Plenty of indicators, why add another?</p>
<p>I shouldn‚Äôt get worked up about a shape, but what I specifically don‚Äôt like about the hexagons are that they create another form of ‚Äúotherism‚Äù; haves and have-nots. HODLers and NGMIs. Two camps. In-group and out-group. It‚Äôs creating division in a place where the world didn‚Äôt need any help creating division. The world doesn‚Äôt need more <em>us</em> versus <em>them</em>, yet we willingly apply feature glitter to increse the divide.</p>
<p>Somewhat apropos to this whole situation we‚Äôve found ourselves in, the hexagon is just a thin veneer of symbolism; a mask applied to the mundane giving it the appearance of something special. An illusion of value.</p>
<p>Transmitted via web2 for obvious reasons.</p>
</description>

        <title>The man playing the ukulele at the doctor‚Äôs office.</title>
        <description><p>I was leaving a doctor‚Äôs appointment and as I rounded the corner to the waiting room I could hear the dulcet tones of a ukulele, but it sounded close.</p>
<p>My first reaction was ‚ÄúWhat in the fuck is going on?‚Äù as I scanned the ceiling for the speaker where the Muzak was coming from. Then in the waiting room I saw an older white man with a ponytail and a Hawaiian shirt calmly strumming his ukulele.</p>
<p>Again, I reacted, ‚ÄúWhat the fuck is going on?‚Äù</p>
<p>Then I caught myself. This‚Ä¶ is‚Ä¶ weird.</p>
<p>Why was he playing it in the doctors office? Was he a minstrel? Was he calming the souls of fellow patients?  A minister? A minister to himself? Does he just love Hawaii and goddamn it ain‚Äôt no one gonna stop him not even the cops at the doctors office?</p>
<p>I think this moment struck me like a ton of bricks because it‚Äôs been awhile since I‚Äôve encountered weird due to the pandemic. Angry? Oh, I‚Äôve encountered plenty of angry. Hot-headed assholes losing their shit in a Chic-fil-A drive thru, yeah I‚Äôve seen that, but been awhile since I‚Äôve seen weird.</p>

        <title>HTML is general, ARIA is specific</title>
        <description><p>In <a href="https://open-ui.org/">Open UI</a> there‚Äôs been some discussion about <a href="https://github.com/openui/open-ui/issues/417">what default ARIA role the proposed <code>&lt;popupdialog&gt;</code> element should have</a>, if any‚Ä¶</p>
<p>The proposed <code>&lt;popupdialog&gt;</code> element is a top-layer element that anchors to another element. Semantically, that‚Äôs a lot like a <em>non-modal</em> <code>dialog</code>, but people will probably use it incorrectly as a <code>listbox</code>, <code>tooltip</code>, <code>combobox</code>, etc. which are not a <code>dialog</code> and have their own more appropriate semantics. Should it be a <code>dialog</code>? Or should it be nothing like a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> or a <code>&lt;span&gt;</code> but sits on the top layer of a website? Should we have other (similar) elements for those specific use cases? Is <code>display: popup</code> the best primitive here?</p>
<p>All good questions and I‚Äôm sure someone smarter than me will provide an answer.</p>
<p>What struck me about it all was how ARIA wants to be specific. It asks elements ‚ÄúWho are you deep down in your soul?‚Äù It‚Äôs a sentry at the gate, asking elements to identify themselves and if the element belongs to or fits within the known lexicon then there are well-defined interaction patterns that work with the Assistive Technology. It‚Äôs all useful and makes sense if you consider aural interfaces.</p>
<p>HTML, in my view, tends to be more general and permissive. A chill uncle. <code>&lt;div&gt;</code>? Sure, that can be a <code>div</code>. <code>&lt;article&gt;</code>? If you think that‚Äôs the article, great, let‚Äôs start there. <code>&lt;video&gt;</code>? Sure, send me some sources and I‚Äôll do my best otherwise I‚Äôll do nothing. Did you use a link for a <code>&lt;button&gt;</code> and a <code>&lt;button&gt;</code> for a link? Aww geeze, Rick. Wish you hadn‚Äôt done that. There‚Äôs right and wrong ways to do HTML, but there‚Äôs often more than one path to a solution. HTML provides a lot of building blocks, spicy divs and spicy spans, sometimes with built-in functionality and semantics, and other times the functionality it‚Äôs all bring-your-own.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a tension there, but I think that‚Äôs what you get in a robust language designed to be liberal in what it accepts but conservative in what it does.</p>
</description>
